{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3610614,"name":"","username":"ThePlatypus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theplatypus/{size}/262128_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T14:35:44.528Z","cooked":"

our team currently use the code of 6328 for our swerve.
we are considering switching to CTRE and we would like to know the pros and cons of using it.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-04T05:15:43.790Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":287,"readers_count":286,"score":177.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":501151,"topic_slug":"ctre-swerve-lib-pros-and-cons","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75643,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/ctre-swerve-lib-pros-and-cons/501151/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3610621,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T14:53:55.122Z","cooked":"

When you say that you’re using “the code of 6328,” are you talking about the AdvantageKit TalonFX swerve template? The AdvantageKit templates specifically exist to enable compatibility with log replay in simulation (note that this is not just normal logging). By contrast, CTRE’s code is not compatible with AdvantageKit or log replay without significant tradeoffs. This is the fundamental difference between those two options.

If you don’t care about log replay (and only want normal logging, for example), the AdvantageKit templates are unlikely to be a good fit; CTRE’s swerve code is probably an appropriate option in that case as long as you have supported hardware. If you care about using log replay specifically, the AdvantageKit templates are probably going to be your best option.

To add onto this, we used the tunerx generated code for about 2 days before switching to the advantagekit code. We got significantly better performance from the advantagekit template than anything else.

Despite a confusing choice of name, Hoot Replay has significantly different functionality from AdvantageKit and deterministic log replay. The page below explains the difference in more detail:

docs.advantagekit.org

Comparison of Log Replay Tools | AdvantageKit

Several logging tools are available to FRC teams with different capabilities and use cases. This page compares non-replay logging tools to several replay-capable logging tools, including AdvantageKit.

No, honestly software and hardware wise anything we did with ctre just kind of worked! Infact we wouldn’t have even got our robot running without the tunerx swerve generator. I guess I should have specific why I like the akit template better.

I like it better because it teaches you more, this being the first year of our team, and the second year of me programming in Java, I found the akit template more intuitive, the way they did it made more sense to me being a novice programmer.

In other words please keep doing what yall are doing because we had no issues with anything ctre wise.

It’s important for us to keep the simulation and log ability

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T18:21:10.757Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":32.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501151,"topic_slug":"ctre-swerve-lib-pros-and-cons","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44471,"username":"jonahb55","name":"Jonah Bonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75643,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/ctre-swerve-lib-pros-and-cons/501151/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3610748,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T18:23:30.258Z","cooked":"

All of the common swerve templates/libraries (AdvantageKit, CTRE, YAGSL) support both simulation and logging; you can visualize that data using AdvantageScope regardless of which option you choose. What the AdvantageKit templates do differently is that they also support deterministic log replay, which means that you can replay the log file to the robot code running in simulation for more complex forms of debugging. This is a more advanced form of logging that’s helpful for niche debugging tasks that normal logging isn’t able to address, but it also requires more experience to use effectively.

When using the AdvantageKit template project, were you able to do everything you needed by viewing log data in AdvantageScope? Or did you find the need to also use the more advanced replay features where you log extra data by replaying the log file to the simulation? (This is what that would look like).
